awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Predictive Analysis of Stability-Critical Structures: an Uncertainty-Informed Path from Measurements to Theory
awd_abstract_narration:
The underlying theme of this Faculty Early Career Development (CAREER) Program award is the development of a unified predictive analysis framework that will significantly improves the state of analysis-based design for stability-critical structures. The framework crosses disciplinary boundaries by bringing together data mining, information theory and statistical inference techniques from data sciences and high fidelity stochastic nonlinear solvers that are based on embedded nonlinear predictors into incremental-iterative path following techniques from computational sciences. Thin-wall structural components such as cold-formed steel members and thin wall cylindrical structures are extremely sensitive to material and fabrication imperfections because they fail in buckling mode when subjected to compressive stresses. The buckling/stability failure mode makes it difficult to predict collapse loads. The challenge in devising predictive analysis framework for components is that a slight deviation from perfection dramatically affects their response to loads. The result is a large scatter in results especially when the response up to collapse load is of interest. Realistic input models for observable and unobservable uncertainties that are adaptable to both global and local scales as well as to stochastic and deterministic methods will be a unique feature of the proposed framework. The goal is to develop analytical non-linear computational model that includes all variables, to integrate research in to curriculum and to provide outreach to community college and high school students. The computational model will be validated with experimental data that is already available.

The methodologies developed in this project will advance the state of the art in computational modeling of stability-critical structures and will create a leap towards moderating large safety factors involved in designing these structures. A new course in probabilistic methods in structural stability will be developed for the PhD curriculum.
org_div_long_name: Division of Civil, Mechanical, and Manufacturing Innovation

por.por_cntn:
Civil infrastructure from bridges to tunnels, and from building to wind turbines, power and communication towers and storage tanks, form the lifeline line of a society. An important class of civil infrastructure comprises those where pushing design efficiency to its limits results in thin-walled components and slender members. The resulting structure then changes its behavior, when subjected to loads, from a more predictable response to a response that is complicated with instabilities and very sensitive to unforeseen and overlooked variabilities. Loss of stability as a limit state, in this class of “stability-critical” structures, from shell instability in a monopole wind tower to buckling of a long span box girder bridge, occurs frequently enough to remind us that this mode of failure has not been eliminated from design practice yet.

One way to deal with the unpredictability of the response is to have as realistic of a model as possible, one that is built by incorporating the measured variabilities into the computational model. The obvious obstacle here is that these variabilities are not known before the structure is built. A more important drawback for such an approach, however, is that it ignores the uncertain nature of such variabilities. As a result, traditional design has coped with this unpredictability by “living on the safe side” in the form of large safety margins, an approach that is obviously counter to the original goal of increasing the design efficiency from the point of view of material use.

The efforts in this project led to the development of approaches that judiciously blend mechanics with accurate measurements of variabilities for modeling stability-critical structures. Analysis frameworks that are “predictive”, in a statistically meaningful way, without overreaching to capture particular sample to sample variabilities were developed by looking at the mechanics of stability-critical structures through an uncertainty-informed lens. This included a comprehensive approach that starts from the development of proper measurement platforms and goes all the way to model construction and consistent (in statistical sense) construction of stochastic process models of variability that are grounded in data. Together, these developments allowed for (i) explaining the variability in mechanical response of stability-critical structures and (ii) development of probabilistic metrics for quantitative validation of “prescribed” initial variability models that are often used by codes and standards to bring a perfect computational model closer to reality. In addition, and in in light of recent advances in additive manufacturing, methodologies were developed that allow for the use of topology-aware models of variability, to study the behavior of thin-walled structures with topological features (e.g. cutouts).

The above outcomes are expected to provide alternatives to large safety margins (or knockdown factors) that are often used to provide lower bounds for the load carrying capacity of stability-critical structures and help engineering mechanics community move towards more reliable, resource-efficient, and resilient designs. The probabilistic insight into how uncertain variabilities impact the behavior of stability-critical structures is expected to lead to (i) important potential long-term improvements in design and analysis strategies currently used in other fields of mechanics that bear similarities to mechanics of stability-critical structures, and (ii) raising awareness on the significant of science-informed modeling approaches to real world problems where uncertainty takes the center stage.

 


Last Modified: 07/20/2022
Modified by: Mazdak Tootkaboni
